awd_titl_txt: Variational Decomposition Models in Imaging Sciences and High Dimensional Multi-Time Hamilton-Jacobi Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Many imaging science problems can be formulated as a variational inverse problem that can be solved using optimization techniques. Imaging models used to process data in order to extract the relevant information for applications are becoming more and more complex and involve many terms. The main objectives of the project consist of establishing new and unique connections between complex variational imaging models and partial differential equations in high dimensions. This connection will be used to better understand, create and learn robust models for processing data to extract the relevant information for applications. The investigator will also use this connection to create new numerical algorithms for solving these optimization problems.

The fundamental research in this project will exhibit new and unique connections between image processing and computer vision techniques based on convex optimization and multi-time Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations in very high dimensions. The research will generate new mathematical results about the robustness of solutions of variational inverse problems in imaging sciences and new formulas that describe the impact of the estimation under perturbations of models. New representation formulas, existence and uniqueness results for a large class of multi-time Hamilton-Jacobi equations will be rigorously obtained.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many imaging science problems can be formulated as a variational inverse problem that can be solved using optimization techniques. Modern imaging models used to extract relevant information in digital images are becoming more and more complex and involve many terms. In this project, we have established novel connections between solutions of these optimization problems arising from imaging sciences and Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations in high dimensions. These novel connections find applications not only in imaging sciences but also optimal control and neural networks that we now describe.

 

We have shown that the minimal values of convex variational problems for image decomposition problems involving many terms is ruled by first-order multi-time Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations. Our findings also describe a novel proof for existence and uniqueness of solution of these Hamilton-Jacobi equation by providing a new perspective from convex analysis. In addition, the variational behaviors of the minimizers subject to a class of perturbations of models were performed. Extensions to non-convex cases have also been considered. These results have been leveraged to propose novel efficient algorithms and to propose novel state of the art model for non-additive noise, such as Poisson and multiple noise. We also have established novel connections between solutions of viscous Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations and a broad class of Bayesian estimators. Specifically, we have shown that solutions to some viscous HJ PDEs with initial data describe a broad class of posterior mean estimators. We used these connections to establish representation formulas and various properties of Bayesian posterior mean estimators. In particular, we used these connections to show that some Bayesian posterior mean estimators can be expressed as solutions to optimization problems.

 

The above connections between optimization in Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations also shows that standard optimization algorithms developed for imaging purposes can also be used for solving high dimensional Hamilton-Jacobi equations that arise from optimal control problems. This interpretation of our results have leveraged to propose several novel algorithms for computing in real-time solutions to certain optimal control involving unmanned aerial vehicles.

 

Finally, the above mathematical analysis connecting optimization problems in imaging sciences and Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations also suggested new connections with neural networks. Specifically, we have exhibited new and original mathematical connections between Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations with initial data and neural network architectures. We proved that some classes of neural networks correspond to representation formulas of Hamilton-Jacobi solutions whose Hamiltonians and initial data are obtained from the parameters of the neural networks. These results do not rely on universal approximation properties of neural networks; rather, our results show that some classes of neural network architectures naturally encode the physics contained in some Hamilton-Jacobi partial differential equations. These novel results do not require any learning stage. Our results naturally yield efficient neural network-based methods for evaluating solutions of some Halmiton-Jacobi partial differential equations in high dimension without using grids or numerical approximations.

 

These finding have been included in undergraduate courses on optimization.
